text: - Hi, everyone.

Thank you for joining us
today for a fireside chat.

I'm Shaown Nandi and I lead
technology for AWS Global Sales,

and I'm super excited to
be here today with Jae,
who is co-founder and CEO of Twelve Labs.

Jae, tell us a bit about
yourself and Twelve Labs.
- Hey, thanks for having me.

Yeah, so Twelve Labs is an AI
research and product company
building video foundation models
for enterprises and developers.

So our focus area isn't
video generation per se,
but more around traditional existing video

understanding problems
like semantic search

across really large archive
or classification video chat
to even now video RAG and video agents.
- That's super exciting.
Look, I was a media CIO for many years
and that would've been mind blowing,
certainly back in the day.

When did you start out?
How did the idea come up?
How did the idea come to you?

- Yeah, so we started
the company pre-ChatGPT,
so March of 2021.
- Oh, so way back.
- Way back.
- From a generative AI perspective.
Recently enough in the world.
- I guess back then, like people,
folks didn't really talk about multimodal

or I don't think like
the term foundation model
was a thing, right?
So I remember like going out pitching
and it was like infrastructural model

and applications are going
to be built on top of this.

No one believed, but then like
it kind of happened, right?

So yeah, and we were seeing
this crazy trend of text, right?

Awesome labs and companies
trying to tackle intelligence
through understanding language.

But then we saw an
opportunity, also frankly,
a really hard challenge of, okay,
can we also tackle like video

and really start working
on perceptual reasoning.

So by the time this awesome
labs and other companies
that are working on language intelligence,

if we can meet and converge
with our perceptual reasoning,
it'd be incredible, right?
So that's how we got started with video.
- That's incredible.
And you've built your own set of models.
- That's right.
- What are they?
Tell us about them.
- Yeah, so our, so we have two models
that we're really proud of.
One is called Marengo.

And Marengo is dedicated for
generating video embeddings.
So really rich multimodal video embeddings

that basically allows you to
power any to any retrieval,
meaning images, audio, video, and text.

This model generates
embeddings from videos
and you can just power search, right?

And then Pegasus model is
our video language model,
which is able to take in user prompts

and the embeddings that
Morengo model generated
and be able to answer your questions
based on your own content, right?
So it gets used for auto report generation
to answering questions that you might have
on certain footage and so on and so forth.

- It sounds like control
after for video almost.
- That's right.
- That's amazing.

So wait, first, before I ask
you more about these models

and how you built them,
how did you come up
with these names?
They're super interesting.

- Yeah, these are the
names of horses, right?
So we love horses at Twelve Labs
because it was the first thing
that was filmed in video, right?
- Oh, I don't think I knew that.

That's so interesting.
- About 100 years ago, right?

So it was basically a bunch
of frames of stallion running,
and that was like the first form of video.
And we wanted to like make sure
it's showcases our commitment.
It's like, hey, we're tackling video
and our model should be named
after the most famous horses, right?

So Marengo is Napoleon's horse,
so everyone knows about it.

And then Pegasus, you know,
the capabilities of that model,
it just feels magical, right?
So it's like, what is that mythical horse?
Pegasus.
- The magical mythical horse.
I love it.
That is an incredible passion for video.
And I bet there are a few people out there

who did not know that horses
were the first thing filmed.
So that's pretty interesting.

So when you built these
two foundation models,
how did you sort of approach this?

Like what was your
approach and mental model

and how did you use,
what kind of tool sets
did you use ultimately?

What were you using today
at least to work with them?
- Yeah, so we do a lot of novel research

around like architecture
model architectures
that's more suited for video, right?

So like the need for video
native video embedding model
is like, was clear to us, right?

Okay, there's a bunch of
like text embedding models
and image embedding models,
but video is an entirely different beast,
so why don't we have it?
So, we should start building it.

And so that's like the
research side of things,
but like the nitty gritty engineering work
that needs to be done, you know,
we don't want to reinvent the wheels.

So, we work really closely
with the HyperPod team, right?
Where we leverage the resilience

and the awesome distributed
training infrastructure

that you've built, which
allows us to actually like

spin up these awesome
GPUs, train the models
as quickly as we can and ship it, right?

And that's like one of
many things that we do.

And video also is like a
very visual thing, right?

So whenever you do things,
you search for things,
visual thing pops up, right?

So, we leverage the streaming
infrastructure media convert

that AWS also invented
and that like allows us

to keep focus on what
we're really good at.

- Tell me a little bit
more about your experience
with SageMaker HyperPod.

How did it really unblock
you in building these models?

- Yeah, I think probably one
of the most challenging thing

about building these kind
of models is, you know,

we are working with really,
really powerful machines

at a incredible scale
from like hundreds of GPUs
to maybe tens of thousands of CPUs.

And even though these are
really well built and robust,

you know, often cases,
very often there are

a lot of like hardware
failures and node failures,
which affects training, right?

And it makes a lot of
scientists go crazy, right?
So, HyperPod, like the promise of reviving

the dead nodes and
resilience and being able

to like basically outsource
high performance computing
was like really appealing to us, right?
So, yeah.
- So you didn't have to think about it.

Your scientists didn't have
to deal with sort of the gorp

of trying to figure out
when a node was killed

or packing problematic
or interrupting training.
They could just sort of go.
- That's right.
That's right.

And I'm sure our scientists
time are better spent.
- [Shaown] Yeah.

- On thinking about the
models, the data than trying
to fix all this crazy hardware issues.

- And tell me a little
bit about how customers,
companies and startups, whoever,
how are they consuming your models?

You mentioned there's lots
of interesting use cases.
- Yeah, yeah.

So I think, you know, this
whole gen AI kind of explosion
is very, very exciting, right?

But I think it started
with like LLMs, right?
But for companies that are video centric
that own large amounts of video content

and that's their source
of kind of revenue,
they feel like they're missing out on,

Hey, where's our version
of enterprise search?

where's our video RAG,
where's our video chat,
video search, right?
So, Twelve Labs help address that, right?
And we bring the gold standard solutions

for these folks to actually
essentially make sense

of petabytes worth of video
archive that they own, right?
So from like media entertainment
and sports to public sectors,
we help all of the videos come searchable.
- That's awesome.
And how do these companies
sort of consume your foundation models?

Do you provide it to them
and they run it themselves,
or what's the mental model there?

- Yeah, so they consume
our models via APIs, right?
Integrate our model capabilities
into their video centric applications
and they build or they enhance.
So that's pretty smooth,
but I think there are deeper integrations

that we're working with that
we're really excited about.
Yeah.

- And tell me about like
some of the challenges
you're seeing with your customers
and they're working with these models.

What are some of the things
you hope you can surmount
to the next months, years, et cetera?
- Yeah, so I think for our customers,

and this is something
that like our customers

and we are also working
together is, I think,

you know, when it comes
to gen AI technology,

because it's so capable,
it's sometimes hard
to stay focused, right?
So knowing what we actually want to power

and how do we evaluate,
properly evaluate the systems
is very important, right?
And also for us as a model provider,

we don't just want to shatter
like academic benchmark, right?

We want to be able to
procure, acquire, and build
a evaluation dataset for our models

that's actually resonant,
like that actually makes sense
for our customers, right?

So these are some of the
things that we're working on
and we're making really good progress.
- That's excellent.

So what do you see coming
next in the future?

Not your roadmap per se,
but what sorts of things

do you think enterprises,
companies, are going to see

from providers like
yourself, model providers?
- Yeah, I think really highly focused

modality specific foundation
models that just nails some

of the existing hair on
fire problems, right?

So for us, you know, we're
starting off with video search,

but you know, being able
to search for things
and retrieve really quickly is like
the foundation of building really,
really robust agent system, right?

So one of our joint customers,
MLSE, Maple Leaf Sports,
they're awesome, awesome people,
pioneers of sports entertainment industry.
They've built this incredible video agent
for post-production, right?

And they were able to kind
of reduce the time it took
to produce a content from like multi weeks
to like multi hours maybe.
- [Shaown] Wow.

- So that's like incredible
amount of efficiency gained
and I think we're just going to see
a lot of that happen, right?

And it's not just going
to come like gradually

because as these systems
become more and more capable

and once the systems
cross certain threshold
and there's just an explosion of use cases
being powered overnight, right?
- I love it.

And so that's interesting
'cause that means companies

are going to be able to get to
their customers, their fans.
They're going to get content to them
so much faster if they can do this.
- That's right.
- Yeah.

- And it's going to
really, really like empower

the viewers too, because
you will now be experiencing
truly personalized content.
A journey basically, right?
You ask these capable systems,

"Hey, these are the
things that I care about.
I like this."
- [Shaown] It comes to.

- And then it just
dynamically gets served.
- That's incredible.
That's incredible.

And tell me a little bit
about like what your customers
are telling you about their experiences.

Obviously you gave a
couple, few great examples,
but what are your customers telling you
about their experience with the models?
- Yeah, great, right?

So, you know, we've been,
so we're really appreciative
and grateful for our customers
and really sharing what they need, right?

It's the ability, well,
the models need to be good,
our models are there, but then the ability
to really quickly fine tune our models
and make it their own, right?

And that's been like working
fantastically, right?

So really empowering
our customers that, hey,

our job is to train really,
really capable base models.

Here's the model and you can
take your proprietary data,
fine tune it, and it's all yours, right?

And that's been like a really,
really awesome experience

that our customers have
been telling us about.

And then once you start
interacting with these models,
the capabilities, they think about a lot
of the crazy use cases that they had

that they stored in the back
burner because it was possible.
- Just wasn't possible.

- Yeah, now they come
out of woodwork, right?
And it gets powered.

- Tell me a little bit about
like how your customers
are working with your models.
Are they tending to fine to them?
Are they doing model distillation?
Are they just using them as is?
What's the experience been like?

- So, Twelve Labs'
models are quite capable.
So in some like general tasks,
our base models just get used, right?

So we have self-serve version
of our models and our APIs,
and these are usually by startups

that are building video
centric applications.

They just go get the API
key and start building.
But then there are customers
that own really, really niche content.

It could be very specific
sports to healthcare domain.
And these are rare footages.

And our customers are
really proud of the data
that they've gathered throughout years.
And we allow them to fine tune our models.
And that model belongs to you,
the fine tuned models, right?
And just building entirely new experiences

on top of their fine tuned
model has been great.
- So how often do you end up having
to release new versions of models

and is it still going
rapid evolution and change,
or what's that pace and timing like?
- Yeah, so we want to be thoughtful
about model releases, right?

But we want to release new
models quite frequently,
but do it in a very thoughtful manner.
Not just like to release new models
for the sake of releasing new models,

but really what are
some of the capabilities
that our models don't have today
that our customers been asking, right?

Once we know that, then we
should iterate fast, right?
So, you know, there's no like,
"Oh, Twelve Labs releases models

in like every four weeks
or two or eight weeks.
Yeah, but once we know exactly what kind

of new capabilities that
we should be adding,

then it's off to the
chases, it's ASAP, right?
- I love it.
That makes so much sense.
Any advice for companies out there

that are consuming models
like yours via API on things

they should look for on how
they should sort of test
and evaluate models, especially ones
that are in unique spaces like yours is?
- Right.
So I think going back first,

I think what's really important,
especially for customers

with lots of video
content, is first knowing
where to put that data, right?
So making sure that infrastructurally
you are set up for success, right?
So, putting data where it needs to be
is harder than you think, you know, right?
So that's important.

Second is like knowing
exactly what you want
and having a robust evaluation dataset

that actually translates
into success, right?

So this dataset is almost
like a north star, right?

With high confidence,
if the model performs
really well on this dataset,

then we can kind of
infer that the production
great solution that you build on top
of our models will be great, right?
And then lastly, making sure

that your training dataset
is in good shape, right?
And you know, I think, and this happens
with like interacting with us.
Come talk to us about your use case

and we can also help
you figure out, right,

'cause this part of like
collective journey, right?
- I love it.

And so I want to thank
you for coming here today
and spending time with us.

We can't wait to see what's
next from Twelve Labs.
It's pretty exciting.

And congratulations on all
your recent model releases.

I know customers are
super excited about it.
- Thank you for having us.
